Award.AwardTitle: Electroweak Symmetry Breaking and Physics Beyond the Standard Model
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award funds the research activities of Professors R. Sekhar Chivukula and Elizabeth H. Simmons at Michigan State University.

The research funded under this grant focuses on uncovering the origins of the masses of the elementary subatomic particles. The next three years will coincide with the 13-TeV high-energy run of the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) at CERN, which will reveal the properties of the newly discovered 126-GeV "Higgs" boson, perform detailed studies of the top quark (the heaviest elementary particle known), and investigate the nature of matter down to the smallest distance scales ever probed. In their research, Professors Chivukula and Simmons will perform theoretical investigations to model the behavior of matter at these short distance scales and predict new phenomena that could be observed at the LHC. This research is in the national interest because it will promote the progress of science in helping to elucidate the fundamental laws governing our universe and deepen our knowledge of the subatomic realm. The proposed project also has several broader impacts. Professors Chivukula and Simmons are leaders in campus and national efforts to improve students' learning and persistence in STEM (science, technology, engineering, and mathematics), especially first-generation students and those from under-represented populations. The PIs will also involve graduate students and postdocs in their research, providing training to junior physicists in research methods and professional preparation to become independent scientists. Finally, the PIs will continue presenting the results of their research in outreach events focused on students from groups underrepresented in science, in order to engage the next generation of scientists.

More technically, Professors Chivukula and Simmons will investigate how electroweak symmetry breaking and the origins of particle masses are impacted by relationships between the Higgs, top quark, and QCD sectors of theories beyond the Standard Model. The PIs will construct and study models in which the Higgs is composite, including those where the top plays a special role in electroweak symmetry breaking and may also be composite. They will derive constraints on these theories from flavor physics and precision electroweak data, emphasizing the phenomenological consequences of the models for the new scalar and other states that may appear at the LHC and future colliders. Professors Chivukula and Simmons will also study models of an extended color sector featuring new colored vector, scalar, or fermion states. The high-energy LHC will dramatically extend our experimental reach for new colored states, and the PIs will systematically investigate how to determine the properties of such a state upon discovery.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report

Award Title: Electroweak Symmetry Breaking Beyond the Standard Model

NSF Award ID: PHY-1519045

PIs: R. Sekhar Chivukula and Elizabeth H. Simmons

Michigan State University & UC San Diego

 

Intellectual Contributions:

 

The intellectual focus of this award has been to theoretically explore the physics accessible at the large hadron collider (LHC) in Geneva, Switzerland, and understand how the interplay of diverse theoretical and experimental constraints impacts the viability of models of physics beyond the standard model.

 

One focus of this work has been to DISTINGUISH BETWEEN DIFFERENT DIJET RESONANCES WHICH COULD BE DISCOVERED AT THE LHC. Many extensions of the standard model of particle physics incorporate new particles which can be produced at the LHC, and which then decay subsequently to a pair of quarks. Each of these quarks appear in the detectors as a spray, or “jet”, of highly collimated sets of hadronic particles (protons, neutrons, pions, and related subatomic particles which have been seen in experiments since the middle of the last century). If such new particles exist, the “dijet” events that would result would be the first indication of new physical laws, and it will be essential to study the properties of these events to determine the nature of the new physics which was uncovered. The PIs, along with their students and postdoctoral collaborators, examined a number of different techniques which could be used to determine the spin and color properties of these new particles, along with examining how their specific decay modes (e.g. into top- or bottom-quarks) can be understood. 

 

The PIs extended their work on dijet resonances to propose a method to derive SIMPLIFIED LIMITS ON NEW RESONANCES AT THE LHC. In the earliest stages of evaluating new collider data, especially if a small new signal may be present, it would be useful to have a method for comparing the data with entire classes of models at once, to get an immediate sense of which classes could conceivably be relevant. The PIs proposed a method that applies when the new physics invoked to explain the excess corresponds to the production and decay of a single such resonance. This method has subsequently been adopted by the CMS collaboration to present some of their results.

 

Another line of investigation has been to UNDERSTAND THE PROPERTIES OF THEORIES THAT INVOLVE EXTENSIONS TO THE STRONG (QCD) INTERACTIONS. The QCD (short for quantum chromodynamics) interactions are mediated by massless gluons and are responsible for binding quarks into protons and neutrons. Extended models of the QCD interactions include everything already observed about the strong interactions, but allow for additional phenomena to emerge at higher experimental energies.  These models include a new set of particles called “colorons”, massive analogs of the gluons. The PIs constructed the simplest consistent theoretical description incorporating these particles, explored the ability of the LHC and future colliders to discover this new physics, and showed that preliminary data from the LHC could have been the first signs of this model.

 

The PIs also undertook a THEORETICAL INVESTIGATION INTO THE CONSISTENCY OF CALCULATIONS INVOLVING THE SCATTERING OF MASSIVE SPIN-2 PARTICLES. In models of gravity which include more than 4 space-time dimensions, the gravitational degrees of freedom include the massless graviton (responsible for ordinary gravity), as well as an infinite tower of interacting massive spin-2 states. We presented the results of the first complete calculation of the scattering amplitudes of these massive spin-2 states and showed that the theory relies on an intricate and surprising set of cancellations between the different contributions in order to produce consistent results. These computations provide a fresh perspective on the theory and phenomenology of such theories and continue to stimulate new theoretical work and insights.

 

Broader Impacts:

 

STEM EDUCATION REFORM: The PIs were leaders in campus and national efforts to improve students’ learning and persistence in STEM.  They especially focused on programs and practices addressing the needs of students from demographic populations traditionally underrepresented in STEM degrees and careers.   LINKING RESEARCH WITH EDUCATION: The PIs gave pedagogical lectures at international graduate summer schools, and mentored graduate students and postdocs on preparation and delivery of conference presentations.  ENGAGED LEARNING: The PIs taught a cross-disciplinary course in mathematical physics serving both undergraduates and beginning graduate students.  They designed the course to use active-learning techniques such as in-class group work, concept mapping, and peer feedback on homework.  They also included independent inquiry components and case studies to bridge the different levels of student preparation. DIVERSITY The PIs gave presentations at local outreach events, mostly focused on female and first-generation students. Simmons extended her national and international efforts to improve the academic and professional climate for women and LBGT+ physicists. RESEARCH DISSEMINATION: Chivukula remained active in the Particle Data Group.
